11.content:
One day, long after Sin and Yu Yevon and all those creepy dead people had been soundly vanquished, FFX-2 happened.

One day, long after FFX-2 happened, Yuna had nothing to do. Ergo, she decided to do something. Simple enough.

And so she began. But another obstacle faced her: what was the something that she would do? She knew that the writers of this story would no doubt like to see her go to the nearest Krispy Kreme (they had just opened a franchise in Besaid) and not leave the place until they had erected a statue in honor of their greatest patron, but she also knew that it was probably in her best interests to find a reason to do something like that before she went off and did it.

Fortunately her Magic 8-Ball was there for her. She moved from the middle of the room (in her house in Besaid) where she was arbitrarily standing to pluck the Magic 8-Ball from an arbitrary shelf in said room. Shaking it, she said, "Should I go down to the Krispy Kreme?"

"SIGNS POINT TO YES," said the Magic 8-Ball, cold and black in her hands.

Yuna then asked, "Why?"

The Magic 8-Ball was shaken and turned upside-down, and it replied "CONCENTRATE AND ASK AGAIN."

So she did, and it said, "DOUBTFUL."

"What," thought Yuna aloud, "does that mean I have doubts about something?" She shook the 8-Ball.

The Magic 8-Ball said "YES DEFINITELY."

"About what?" Shake.

"MY SOURCES SAY NO."

Yuna thought about this. While normally a particularly intelligent person (in spite of which she fell in love with Tidus (who in their right mind would do that?)) she was bored, and as a result her brain was temporarily melted. It was the middle of summer, and the heat didn't help either. After (not) much soul-searching, the young ex-summoner came to the conclusion that the Magic 8-Ball had decided not to tell her what she was doubtful about.

But, she could not think what it was. So she asked. "Won't you please give me some sort of hint?" Shake,

"SIGNS POINT TO YES."

Okay, Yuna thought. Maybe it wants me to play a guessing game. "Is it smaller than a breadbox?" Shake.

"NO."

"Okay.... Will it probably change my life if I solve it?" Shake

"MOST LIKELY."

"Will I find out if I go and eat a lot of Krispy Kremes?" Shake.

"TRY AGAIN LATER."

Yuna thought about this, but she was beginning to get impatient. She shook the Magic 8-Ball fiercely, but she accidentally dropped it!

It broke against her hard stone floor and out popped a funny little man, who was green and floatey and transparent and had a very annoyed expression on his face.

Yuna, her eyes wide, asked it "Are you a genie?"

"No," said the funny little annoyed ghost-man. "I'm the spirit of the Magic 8-Ball. And let me say, you've been asking me some very stupid questions. And you dropped me. But it's my job to answer questions. So, go ahead." But the funny little man did not say that being free from the 8-Ball entitled him to give false answers, nor did he say that he was probably going to do so because he hated Yuna's guts for some reason.

"Okay," said Yuna. "What am I doubtful about?"

The funny little man braced himself, as though he was about to be shaken wildly, but when he noticed that the room was staying still, he opened his eyes and cleared his throat, thinking of the lie he could tell that would be most likely to get this woman to do something stupid and embarassing. "Well, you see..." he began, before continuing, "you are doubtful about your body. You aren't sure you're beautiful."

"I'm not?" asked Yuna, amazed. This guy was good; even she didn't know that!

"Of course not!" he snapped. "You aren't sure you're beautiful," he said again, "and you... you want to try something different with yourself. Yeah, that's it."

"So..." said Yuna, "I... should go to Krispy Kreme?"

"Yes," said the funny little man.

"Great!" said Yuna, before running out of her door down to the heavenly doughnut franchise.

The funny little man looked out the door and called after her,

11111222.content:
"Does eight thousand gil sound good to you?" Yuna asked, looking pleadingly at Rikku.

Rikku reached into her wallet and withdrew the desired sum, handing it to Yuna. "Just don't overdo it, okay Yuna?"

" I won't." She smiled devilishly with a mischevious glint in her eye.

Yuna made her way back to the Krispy Kreem, slamming the gil down on the counter and demanding four boxes of the Ultima doughnut. The cashier obliged, rolling her eyes at Yuna as she tore into the boxes before she even had a chance to sit down.

A few off-duty guardsmen sat at a table, watching in fascination at the woman who ate more than they could hope to stomach. Anyone with enough money to afford that many Ultima donuts would have to have money to burn. Seeing a potential to make some easy money off of a wager, one of them walked up to Yuna.

"Hungry one aren't you?" he said, raising an eyebrow.

Yuna looked up from her half finished box, blushing a deep red out of embarrassment, swallowing her last bite.

"Not really, I just can't stop myself."

"Well, I'll tell you something, me and my buddies over there are on break, and frankly, we don't have anything to do, so we thought we could play a little game with you."

"What kind of game?" Yuna asked while finishing another box.

"You seem to be one with a high tolerance for stuffing yourself silly, so we thought that we could make a wager with you. Olaf over there is the fattest man in the guard, I've seen him finish whole buffets without blinking. If you were to, say 'eat him under the table' we could give you a card that lets you buy from any doughnut shop in town for a quarter of the price."

Speechless, Yuna looked at him. She glanced at the last box which was to her horror, empty. Her stomach growled in protest, but something in the recesses of her mind told her she wasn't finished yet.

"What if I lose?" She said as she covered a burp.

"Then we get twenty thousand gil."

She knew that she didn't have that kind of money, but she accepted anyway.

"The rules are simple, ten boxes of regular donuts to each of you. If you are unable to continue, the winner must finish both their portion and the last part of the loser's portion."

They sat down at the guardsmen's table, and had an unbelievable stack of twenty boxes set before them.

She groaned upon the sight of this, causing the guardsmen to snicker in anticipation.

"You may begin." said the Guard who had approached her earlier.

It began easliy enough, the first two boxes before Yuna were emptied before long, but she struggled on the third. Olaf was on his fourth and showed no signs of stopping. She was losing and she knew it.

Digging into her inner resolve, she found the fortitude to continue her binge. Despite her stomach screaming in agony at the strain, she continued to her final box, which to her horror, were not regular donuts at all, but were a dozen eclairs, fit in a position that allowed them to fit in a regular box.

It was upon the last box, that Olaf's eyes rolled into the back of his head, and then collapsed on the floor.

"Time for the home stretch, little girl." One of the spectators said.

"Haven't I already stretched enough?" Yuna said, fighting back tears of pain in her eyes and pointing to her stomach, which was red and swollen beyond recognition.

"You know the rules. Finish the box!"

Finding her last reserves of strength, she forced the last of the eclairs down her throat.

"Well, I can't say I expected that." The lead guardsman said begrudgingly. "Well, a deal is a deal, you win." He reached into his wallet and threw a platinum colored card in forn of her.

"That one lets you eat all you want for free, there's only three of those in the city, so consider yourself lucky."

She nodded her head, and slipped it into her pocket.

The guardsmen left and, Yuna barely able to stand, got up and walked outside. Her graceful stride had devolved into and uncomely waddle as she struggled with her new found girth. Tired beyond belief, she fell asleep on a park bench were she slept for a few moments before a bitter looking old lady walked by.

"He left you like that didn't he? Typical man, one night in the bed and then when faced with responsibility, takes off with his drinking buddies." The crone said.

Yuna woke up groggily and rubbed her eyes. "Pardon?" she yawned.

"There's no need to defend him, it's clear to me that he dumped you on the streets before he had to take care of his own child."

As she came into focus, she struggled to understand what the old woman said, then it came to her. Her previous binge left her looking about nine months pregnant.

Yuna said nothing and let the old crone rant.

"Well, now that he isn't here, I might as well lend you a hand, as my husband left me for the same reasons, though..." She held an expensive looking signet placed on her in between her index and middle finger looking at it her own reflection in the flawlessly cut ruby. " I wasn't without my resources.

"He lost the lawsuit and then he was the one living on the streets." She said with a chuckle. "Lost his whole business empire to me, I liquidated it and kept the money for myself. Unfortunately, due to complications, my daughter died during childbirth, so I've no heir to my fortunes."

The strange old woman pulled out a piece of parchment and signed it. "Sign here." she said, handing the pen and paper to Yuna. "My will."

Yuna signed it and the old crone began cackling in triumph. "See that you miserable old sod!?" I win, the money will never go to your brother!" She said, raising a bony fist to the sky. Taking the pen and parchment away, she left, as quickly as she had arrived.

Then Yuna felt an all too familiar grumbling of her stomach.

11211.content:
After a healthy breakfast and a quick jog around the island to keep her stamina and strength up, Yuna returned home only to find her teammates Paine and Rikku waiting eagerly for her. Or, as eagerly as Paine could. Rikku was fairly bouncing off the walls.

"Yunie Yunie Yunie! We found a new sphere in the Zanarkand ruins!" Rikku burst out, running up to her cousin. "Shinra thinks it's something really good! Something about the whatsit waves or whatever..."

"The fluctuations of power coming from the reading." Paine clarified, walking forward and placing her hands on her hips. "It's supposedly a relic from before even the era of Zanarkand, buried deep inside the main dome."

"Really? It might have some interesting data on it, then..." Yuna said, placing her chin in her hand. "Let's go for it!" She finally said, nodding firmly with a bright smile on her face.

-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

"Nearing the Zanarkand Ruins...you girls better get ready." the navigator of the Celsius, Buddy, called down, tapping away at his computer as Brother, the pilot, guided the airship in smoothly.

"We're all ready for the drop off." Yuna called as the hatch opened, the three girls hopping down and landing gracefully outside of the large, ominous dome. "We'll keep in touch!"

"You be careful Yuna! You sure you don't want me there?" Brother called over the comm link, his voice plaintive and begging.

"I'm sure. I'll keep you posted, though." She chuckled as the group trooped inside, the pyreflies dancing and glimmering in the gloom. The three stolid adventurers trooped through the crumbling ruins of the dome, eventually reaching the former Trials.

"Wow...this brings back memories...of making Tidus do manual labor!" Rikku giggled, while Yuna smiled and walked through the door to the lift room.

"Yeah...it's been so long since we came through here to fight Yunalesca...that's where the energy reading is coming from, right Paine?" Yuna asked, sitting on the steps leading up to the now blank monitor.

"Down the lift and straight through the room holding the Fayth statue..." she replied, pocketing Shinra's portable sphere-tracker. "Though the sphere is moving now..."

"Really?! That must mean LeBlanc is here!" Rikku yelped, scrambling for the lift as fast as she could. Yuna and Paine exchanged glances before following along.
